They should not be hasty, and it is even inappropriate to ask for Allah's punishment to be hastened, because if the punishment comes as they request, they will certainly not be able to reject or prevent it. On the contrary, a reasonable request from them would be that Allah's punishment not come. For that, they should believe in Allah and obey His commands and abandon His prohibitions, as has been conveyed to them.
text.34: In this verse, Allah explains the continuation of Prophet Noah's (peace be upon him) response and clarification to his rebellious people, that whatever was conveyed to them in the form of advice to invite them to the right path and warn them to avoid Allah's punishment in this world and the hereafter, would be of no benefit if they remained misled by the temptations of their desires (hawa nafsu). That is what caused their destruction in this world and eternal torment in the hereafter. Furthermore, Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) explained to them that indeed Allah is their Lord who owns and regulates this world, so that everything happens according to His provisions, measures, and will. Everything will return to Him in the hereafter to receive the reward for their deeds, whether good or bad, according to their actions in this world.
text.35:
According to Ibn Kathir's opinion, this verse is a continuation of the story of the people of Noah (peace be upon him), explaining that they accused Noah (peace be upon him) of giving incorrect and fabricated advice and warnings. So Allah taught Noah (peace be upon him) to say to them that if he fabricated it, then he himself would bear the sin, and that the accusation was completely untrue.

According to the opinion of some other commentators (mufassir), this verse is not a continuation of the story of the people of Noah (peace be upon him), but an interpolated sentence (jumlah mutaridhah). According to them, the meaning of this verse is that after the disbelievers of Mecca heard the story of the people of Noah (peace be upon him) from Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him), they accused him of fabricating the story. Therefore, Allah taught the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) to say to them that if he fabricated it, he himself would bear the sin. But what they accused him of was completely untrue, and he was free from the actions they accused him of.
text.36:
In this verse, Allah recounts that He revealed to Prophet Noah to explain the following:

a. After Noah's people requested that Noah (peace be upon him) immediately bring Allah's punishment as proof of the truth of his da'wah, and Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) had prayed for them to be destroyed by Allah, then no one among them believed except for a few, namely only those who had declared their faith in him before that.

b. Even though Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) had lived with his people for hundreds of years conveying da'wah to them, they still remained defiant. This did not make him grieve or be sad thinking about their attitude and behavior that remained unbelieving, because the punishment of Allah's retribution upon them in this world was near, and they would not be able to avoid or prevent it.

(37) According to a narration from Ibn Abbas, the length of the ship was one thousand two hundred cubits. In this verse, it is explained that Allah commanded Noah (peace be upon him) to build a ship that would be used to save Prophet Noah and his believing followers from the flood (deluge) that would strike and submerge the surface of the earth as a punishment in this world for the disbelievers from his people who were always defiant and disobedient. Prophet Noah was commanded to build the rescue ship with guidance and supervision from Allah.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah warns Noah (peace be upon him) not to speak to his zalim (kafir) people again and not to plead for their sins to be forgiven or to be spared from His punishment, because it has become Allah's decree that they will be drowned.

A similar prohibition was also given to Prophet Abraham (peace be upon him) when he pleaded with Allah that His punishment not be inflicted upon the people of Lot, as mentioned in His word:

"O Abraham! Give up this plea. Indeed, the command of your Lord has come, and they will be overtaken by a punishment that cannot be repelled." (Hud/11: 76)
text.37:
According to a narration from Ibn Abbas, the length of the ship was one thousand two hundred cubits. In this verse, it is explained that Allah commanded Noah (peace be upon him) to build a ship that would be used to save Prophet Noah and his believing followers from the flood (deluge) that would inundate and submerge the surface of the earth as a punishment in this world for the disbelievers from his people who were always defiant and disobedient. Prophet Noah was commanded to build this rescue ship with guidance and supervision from Allah.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah warns Noah (peace be upon him) not to speak further with his unjust (disbelieving) people and not to plead that their sins be forgiven or that they be spared from His punishment, because it has become Allah's decree that they will be drowned.

A similar prohibition was also given to Prophet Abraham (peace be upon him) when he pleaded with Allah that His punishment not be inflicted upon the people of Lot, as mentioned in His saying:

"O Abraham! Give up this plea. Indeed, the decree of your Lord has come, and they will be overtaken by a punishment that cannot be repelled." (Hud/11: 76)
text.38:
In this verse, it is explained that Noah (peace be upon him) built the ark of salvation according to the commands and instructions revealed to him by Allah. Many narrations or opinions are quoted by the commentators of the Quran (mufassirun) regarding matters related to the ark, such as what kind of wood it was made of, where it was built, what its shape was, how long and wide it was, and other details, some of which have been explained when discussing verse 37 before this. The best opinion in this matter from a faith-based perspective is as explained by Shihabuddin Mahmud Al-Alusi in his commentary, Ruhul Maaniy, as follows:

"A careful person in this matter will not lean towards excessive details, but will only believe that Noah (peace be upon him) built the ark as narrated by Allah in His Book, and will not seek to know about its length, width, and height, what kind of wood it was made of, how long it took to build, and other things that are not explained by the Book of Allah and the authentic Sunnah of His Messenger."

Furthermore, this verse explains that every time Noah's people passed by and saw him building the ark, they mocked him with various questions that were sarcastic. This mockery and ridicule arose because they all did not yet know about ships and how to use them, including the Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) himself. Noah's (peace be upon him) attitude in responding to the mockery and ridicule of his people is stated in his answer, "If you mock us for building this ark because we are obeying Allah's command in an effort to save ourselves and our people, then we will also mock you."

Some commentators of the Quran (mufassirun) are of the opinion that what is meant by Noah's (peace be upon him) retaliatory mockery is the worldly punishment that will befall his people, so he will no longer care about them. So Noah (peace be upon him) himself did not retaliate with mockery, because it is considered inappropriate for a prophet. Others are of the opinion that there is nothing wrong if the retaliatory mockery really came from Noah (peace be upon him) in accordance with Allah's words:

And whoever attacks you, then attack him in the same way as he has attacked you. (al-Baqarah/2: 194)

And Allah's words:

And if you punish [an oppressor], punish him with an equivalent of that with which you were harmed. (an-Nahl/16: 126)

And Allah's words:

And the retribution for an evil act is an evil one like it. (ash-Shura/42: 40)

Al-Alusi is of the opinion that both mockeries (the mockery of Noah's people and the mockery of Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) as a response) did indeed occur.
text.39: This verse explains the continuation of Prophet Noah's (peace be upon him) words to his people who mocked him, saying that if they didn't yet know the purpose of the ship he was building, they would surely find out after the ship was finished and they were drowned. In reality, Prophet Noah's (peace be upon him) words were not merely a response to their mockery, but a threat of impending punishment. Because when they realized it, they would surely feel that Prophet Noah's (peace be upon him) words were no longer just ordinary words that they always considered mere scare tactics that would never materialize. But this time, it was already in the preparation stage to save the believers from the danger of punishment that would destroy those who were very disobedient to Allah and His Messenger.
text.40:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that Prophet Noah a.s., in carrying out the construction of the ship with all its preparations, was very diligent and received much ridicule and mockery from his people. When Allah's decree came to destroy the disbelieving people, the earth gushed forth water that overflowed like boiling water from a pot in the kitchen, submerging everything on its surface. Some scholars understand that the flood was not universal but local.

Then Allah commanded Noah a.s. to bring into the ship a pair (male and female) of each type of animal, so that their offspring could multiply after the flood, called the deluge, subsided. In addition, Allah commanded Noah a.s. to bring into the ship all his family members, male and female, except those who did not believe. Likewise, Allah commanded Noah a.s. to bring into the ship all the believers, whose number was small. Some commentators (mufasir) say that those brought by Noah into the ship from his family were his believing wife and three sons from that believing wife, namely Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

As for the number of believers that Noah a.s. brought into the ship, there is no explanation in the Al-Quran or in the hadith. In this verse, it is only explained that their number was small. At the beginning of this verse and the beginning of verse 42 to come, a part of the story of the deluge is depicted, and in other verses, it is depicted in more detail, as in Allah's words:

So We opened the gates of the sky with rain pouring down. And We caused the earth to burst forth with springs, and the waters met for a matter already decreed. And We carried him on that [ship] of planks and nails, sailing under Our observation as reward for he who had been denied. (al-Qamar/54: 11-14)
text.41:
This verse explains that Noah (peace be upon him) commanded those who believed in his message to board the ark, invoking the name of Allah at the time of its sailing and its anchoring, because all power is in His hands. He can do as He wills, arranging His laws according to His Will; while their safety at that crucial moment was only under His power, within His protection.

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "My ummah will be safe (not drown) if they board a ship and recite: *Bismillahi malikirrahmanirrahim, bismillahi majreha wa mursaha innahu lagafururrahim.*" (Narrated by Ath-Thabrani from Ali)

Furthermore, this verse explains that Noah (peace be upon him) declared, "Indeed, my Lord is Forgiving and Merciful." This statement, besides containing gratitude, indicates that he and his believing followers were saved from the danger of the flood thanks to Allah's vast mercy.
text.42:
This verse explains that the ship sailed, carrying Noah (peace be upon him) and his followers, those who believed, across a vast ocean and through terrifying waves, rolling and towering like mountains.

After Prophet Noah and his followers entered the ship, he saw his son, named Canaan, going towards the mountain, distancing himself. Prophet Noah called out to his son, inviting him to join them on the ship, but his son refused, causing Prophet Noah to feel sad and worried.

The scholars differ in opinion as to whether Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) was unaware of the true state of his son before this event. Some are of the opinion that Noah (peace be upon him) was indeed unaware, because before the event, his son acted hypocritically towards him. Another opinion states that he knew of his son's disbelief, but after his son witnessed for himself that the storm had begun, Noah hoped for his son's awareness, so he invited him to enter the ship, but his efforts were in vain because his son still refused.
text.43:
In this verse, Allah mentions Kanan's response to the call and invitation of his father, Noah (peace be upon him), to enter the ark. He refused to join, reasoning that he could take refuge on a mountain to protect himself from the danger of the flood (storm) that threatened.

Hearing this, Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) explained to his disobedient son that on that day, nothing could protect anyone from the storm except Allah, and no one would be saved except those whom He had mercy on, namely those who entered the ark. Thus, the will (iradah) of God had determined that everything would proceed according to the process He had ordained. The waves, rolling high with such ferocity, separated Noah (peace be upon him) from his rebellious and disobedient son, so that the conversation between them was cut off, and the son also drowned with the other disbelievers.
text.44:
In this verse, it is explained that a flood (deluge) struck the surface of the earth, causing springs to gush forth abundantly, in addition to torrential rainfall. Noah's ark sailed through the raging ocean with tremendous force, and it was unknown when this would end. Then the time came when Allah commanded the earth to absorb the water it had emitted and commanded the sky to stop its rainfall, so the water receded and Allah's command was perfectly fulfilled, and all the disbelievers from Noah's people drowned. Then the ark came to rest on Mount Judiy.

Then, at the end of this verse, Allah curses the disbelievers with His words, "Away with the wrongdoing people." The meaning is: The flood event was to destroy the wrongdoers (disbelievers) who were far from Allah's mercy, because of their wrongdoing and their unwillingness to repent and return to the right path. The great flood in the time of Prophet Noah certainly did not submerge the entire surface of the earth, but occurred in a very large area in and around the Dead Sea, which is indeed lower than sea level.
text.45:
In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) pleaded with God to save his son, named Canaan or Yam, from the flood, because his son was part of his family and God had promised that his family would be saved from the flood, and God's promise is true, unchanging, and He is the Wisest of all judges. This prayer of Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) occurred before his son drowned, after he called and invited him to come aboard the ark.

Although Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) did not know that he, after being commanded by God to build the ark, was still permitted to pray for the disbelievers, while his son had clearly disobeyed and refused to be invited into the ark, he was not yet certain that his son was among the disbelievers who should also be drowned, especially since he was driven by the affection of a father towards his son.
text.46:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah rejected Noah's (a.s.) request that his son, Canaan, be spared from the torment of the flood. Allah explained that Canaan, who refused to enter the ark, was not included in his family whom Allah swt had promised to save from the flood, because the son had committed evil deeds. He refused to enter the ark and refused to accept true guidance, even though the guidance came from his own father, who was a messenger of Allah. He remained stubborn and rebellious along with the other disbelievers and had to be drowned in the flood. Allah does not differentiate between people except by their piety (taqwa), regardless of skin color, nation, or lineage.

Allah forbade Noah (a.s.) from asking Him about something he did not know with certainty whether the request was appropriate to make or not. Furthermore, Allah warned Noah (a.s.) not to be among the ignorant people who ask Him for something according to the desires of their ego (nafs) or for the benefit of their family and loved ones without knowing what is permissible and appropriate to ask for.

This verse contains several laws and guidance, including:

a. It is not permissible to ask Allah for something inappropriate that contradicts the sunnah of Allah or that is not yet known whether the request is appropriate or not.

b. Everyone who opposes the truth shown by Allah and His Messenger will receive a punishment.
text.47: This verse explains Prophet Noah's (peace be upon him) understanding of Allah's rebuke, which contained the rejection of his request for his son Canaan to be saved from the flood. Thus, after Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) learned from Allah the true nature of his son, he sought forgiveness from Him for his error and mistake in requesting something that was inappropriate. He sought refuge in Allah so that he could protect himself from making requests similar to that mistake. At the end of his plea for forgiveness, with sincerity and devotion, he expressed his regret to Allah. If his mistake was not forgiven by God, he would surely be among the losers, because his mistake was only driven by the affection of a father for his son and the desire for his son to receive Allah's mercy.
text.48:
This verse explains that after the ship docked on Mount Judiy for an unspecified period of time – "according to some mufassir, for a month" – and the floodwaters had receded, Allah commanded Noah (peace be upon him) to disembark from the ship along with his followers to build a new life in order to continue the generation of monotheistic and pious people, after the disbelievers from his people were destroyed by drowning in the torment of the flood.

Allah commanded Noah (peace be upon him) and his followers to disembark from the ship with greetings of peace and full of blessings from Him. They would be blessed, according to Allah's promise, in their worldly and afterlife lives. After they descended to land, they received abundance in sustenance and the necessities of life that they needed for their benefit and the benefit of future generations.

Furthermore, Allah explains that not all of their descendants who would multiply in the future would be the same as them. However, among the descendants who multiplied, there would be communities who could only enjoy worldly sustenance and pleasures, but in the Hereafter they would receive a very painful torment. They were misled by Satan, becoming polytheists and wallowing in injustice and other evils, so that they could not maintain security and prosperity, and some even oppressed others. They were scattered and disagreed, deviating from the guidance of the religion brought by the messengers of Allah.

According to the explanation of Taqiyuddin al-Maqrizi, none of the followers of Prophet Noah had descendants except for his three sons (Shem, Ham, and Japheth). This opinion is based on the word of Allah:

And We made his descendants those who remained [on the earth]. (ash-Saffat/37: 77)
text.49:
In this verse, Allah swt explains to Prophet Muhammad saw that the story of Noah a.s. and the stories of other prophets are important news that are included in matters of the unseen (ghaib) that Allah revealed to him, which he had never known before, nor had his people known before that, so that they could accuse him of obtaining the story from others. But it is Allah who revealed the story to Muhammad in accordance with the actual events as explained in the books of the previous prophets. If any of his people had ever heard of it, their knowledge would only be global and vague.

Therefore, even though they threw various accusations at Muhammad saw, Allah commanded him to be patient in the face of his people who caused him much heartache; just as Noah a.s. was patient in the face of his people who mocked and ridiculed him for hundreds of years. This has become the sunnah of Allah for His messengers. Nevertheless, the end result is victory and good fortune for those who are pious and patient. Conversely, defeat and loss will befall those who rebel against the truth and those who do evil. This is in accordance with other verses such as the word of Allah:

Indeed, We will support Our messengers and those who believe during the life of this world and on the Day the witnesses will stand. (al-Mumin/40: 51)

The Quran does not explicitly state how old Prophet Noah a.s. was, but it is only mentioned in His word as follows:

And We certainly sent Noah to his people, and he remained among them a thousand years minus fifty years, and then the flood overtook them while they were wrongdoers. (al-Ankabut/29: 14)

Clearly, the verse only states that Noah a.s. lived among his people for nine hundred and fifty years. It is possible that this period of time only refers to the period of time in conveying the da'wah to his people. And it is also possible that that is the total number of his years, including the period of conveying the da'wah.
text.50:
This verse explains that Allah sent His messenger to the people of 'Ad, who resided north of Hadramaut in Yemen and west of Oman. That messenger of Allah was Hud (peace be upon him), whom Allah chose from the 'Ad people themselves, so that it would be easier to convey and instill faith in them. According to some narrations quoted by some commentators (mufassir), it is said that Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) was the first person to speak Arabic and the first messenger of Allah from the Arab people, a descendant of Noah (peace be upon him). In this verse, Allah uses the *uslub* or style of *ijaz*, which is concise and dense, namely "to the 'Ad people, their brother Hud," meaning, "We sent to the 'Ad people one of them named Hud." This type of grammar is often used in the Al-Quran.

Hud (peace be upon him), as a messenger of Allah, began to call his people to worship Allah, the One and Only God, there is no god but Him. Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) forbade them from worshiping statues and idols, because such actions are associating partners with God (shirk) and fabricating falsehoods by claiming that the statues and idols they worship are helpers who can provide benefits and ward off harm. Whereas, those statues were made by humans.
text.51:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that Hud a.s., in conveying his message to his people, did not ask for any wages or payment whatsoever, so they could not accuse him of seeking personal gain. He only hoped for reward from Allah, Who created him as a human being with a sound mind and who could free himself from worshiping the idols made by the people of Noah a.s. These idols were made to commemorate the services of their pious ancestors. In reality, they fell into the abyss of shirk because they were manipulated by the deception of Satan, which was initially intended for honoring and glorifying, but ultimately became objects of worship.

Then, Prophet Hud a.s. encouraged his people to use their sound minds, so that they could distinguish between what is beneficial and what is harmful to them. He also said that he was advising them and showing them the right path only for their safety and happiness in this world and the hereafter. But they refused to follow him.
text.52:
This verse explains that Hud, peace be upon him, after inviting his people to worship the One God and forbidding them from associating partners with Him by worshipping idols, commanded them to ask forgiveness from Allah and then repent with full sincerity. Furthermore, Hud, peace be upon him, explained that if they acted as he had advised, Allah would surely send down abundant rain, which would be of great benefit to them as a nation with many plants and gardens. Allah would also increase the strength and glory they desired, in addition to what they already possessed. Therefore, Prophet Hud, peace be upon him, warned his people not to turn away from the truth that had been advised to them and not to continue the great errors they had become accustomed to, namely worshipping idols, statues, and falling into other evil deeds. The people of Hud, peace be upon him, who were called the nation of 'Ad, or the tribe of 'Ad, or the people of 'Ad, were not only known as a wealthy nation in the field of agriculture, but they were also known as strong people with sturdy bodies, which caused them to become increasingly arrogant and conceited, as explained by Allah in His word:

"As for 'Ad, they were arrogant upon the earth without right and said, "Who is greater than us in strength?" Did they not consider that Allah who created them was greater than them in strength? And they were rejecting Our signs. So We sent upon them a screaming wind during days of misfortune to make them taste the punishment of disgrace in the worldly life; but the punishment of the Hereafter is more disgracing, and they will not be helped." (Fushshilat/41: 15-16)
text.53: In this verse, Allah SWT explains the challenge of the people of Hud (peace be upon him) to the da'wah (call to Islam) conveyed by Hud (peace be upon him) by rebelling and saying that Hud (peace be upon him) did not provide any clear evidence whatsoever to demonstrate his truthfulness as a messenger of Allah, who was assigned to convey the da'wah to them. Therefore, they would not abandon the worship of idols and statues simply because they heard his unreasonable words, and they declared that they would not believe in him. This harsh challenge from the people of Hud was initially based on the absence of clear evidence presented by Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) to them regarding his truthfulness as a messenger of Allah. However, if one observes the manner, style, and content of their challenge, it can be concluded that they were essentially rebelling, not because of the absence of clear evidence or arguments. With such a challenge, they could no longer be expected to believe.
text.54: This verse explains the continuation of the challenge from the people of Hud (peace be upon him), namely by saying to him that Hud's words were similar to the words of someone possessed by a jinn. They could not accept these words at all, especially the words that belittled and hindered them from worshiping idols. This challenge was apparently followed by an even harsher challenge than before. They accused Hud (peace be upon him) of suffering from madness, so there was no need to listen to his words, let alone believe them. This madness, according to their assumption, was caused by Hud (peace be upon him) being disobedient to their deities. That is why Prophet Hud (peace be upon him) concluded that his da'wah would no longer be useful for them, so he answered their challenge by saying that he testified to Allah and ordered them to witness that he was indeed free from what they associated with Him. This answer from Hud (peace be upon him) demonstrates a firm attitude, full of faith in taking responsibility for the truth of his da'wah, which was conveyed to his people regardless of all kinds of obstacles and challenges he faced.
text.55:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the continuation of Prophet Hud a.s.'s response to his people with something harsher and imbued with full courage to be accountable for the truth of his da'wah (call to Islam).

With a challenging tone, Hud a.s. ordered his very rebellious people to unite all of them together with their gods in carrying out all kinds of trickery to destroy him immediately, without giving him the opportunity to prepare beforehand to defend himself. This answer clearly shows that Hud a.s. was not afraid at all of his disbelieving people, let alone their gods who could not do anything. Similar words were once spoken by Prophet Nuh a.s. to his people, as explained in Allah's word:

"Therefore, resolve upon your plan, you and your partners, and let not your plan be obscure to you. Then execute it upon me and give me no respite." (Yunus/10: 71)
text.56: In this verse, Allah swt explains the words of Hud a.s. in response to the challenge of his people. After he commanded them to gather together with their gods in carrying out all kinds of deception to destroy him, he declared that he had placed his complete trust in Allah, his Lord, and also their Lord who created the universe. There is no creature that crawls upon this universe that is not under His control, and Allah is Most Just, guiding His servants on the straight path, helping those who are truthful, and oppressing the wrongdoers. Thus, Hud a.s.'s answer to his people, which had a tone of bold defiance, was not driven by arrogance, pride, or anything of the sort, but by the faith that had been forged in the depths of his heart to take responsibility for the truth of the da'wah he conveyed to his people. Hud a.s. was certain that the disbelievers among his people would not be able to do anything outside of Allah's decree and will. Thus, his tawakkal arose in accordance with Allah's encouragement, as mentioned in His word:
text.57:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the concluding remarks of Hud a.s. to his people by reminding them that if they turn away from what he has conveyed and continue to deny him as a messenger of Allah, then he can do no more than that, because he has carried out the da'wah entrusted to him by Allah. This trust has been fulfilled sincerely, and his duty is only to convey. Therefore, if they still challenge and rebel, then the punishment of Allah will be inflicted upon them, and Allah will replace them with another people.

Furthermore, Hud a.s. affirms that they will not be able to cause any harm to Allah, either by turning away from faith or by any other means. Indeed, Allah is the All-Preserver of everything meticulously, in accordance with His sunnah determined by His iradah, including helping His messengers and inflicting punishment upon their enemies.

Hud a.s.'s affirmation to his people that they will not be able to cause any harm to Allah by turning away from faith and remaining in disbelief is not merely a warning to frighten them, but it is indeed the reality and the truth, and this is in accordance with the word of Allah:

"If you disbelieve, then indeed, Allah is free from need of you. And He does not approve for His servants disbelief. But if you are grateful, He approves it for you..." (az-Zumar/39: 7)

And the word of Allah:

"Then worship what you will besides Him." Say, "Indeed, the losers are the ones who will lose themselves and their families on the Day of Resurrection." (az-Zumar/39: 15)
text.58:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that when Allah's punishment came to the people of Hud A.S. as a result of their disobedience, Prophet Hud A.S. and his believing followers were saved by Allah from that very severe worldly punishment as a mercy and favor from Allah to them, and He will save them from the more severe punishment of Allah in the Hereafter. As for the people of Hud A.S. who continued to oppose and disobey, they were all destroyed and will receive a more severe punishment in the Hereafter.

As for the punishment of Allah that was inflicted upon the people of Hud A.S., it was in the form of a very cold and strong wind, as mentioned in the word of Allah:

"And as for 'Ad, they were destroyed by a furious wind, which He imposed upon them for seven nights and eight days in succession, so you would see the people therein fallen as if they were hollow trunks of palm trees. Then do you see of them any remnant remaining?" (al-Haqqah/69: 6-8)
text.59:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that this is the story of the people of 'Ad who denied the signs of Allah's power and disobeyed His messenger who was sent to guide them to the right path, which is to single Him out in worship and obey His commands. But they only wanted to obey the commands of tyrannical rulers who refused to follow the truth even with sufficient and convincing arguments and evidence.

In this verse, it is explained that the people of 'Ad (the people of Hud a.s.) disobeyed the messengers of Allah. Is this really the case? Or did they only disobey one messenger of Allah, namely Hud a.s.? The commentators of the Quran explain that what they denied was Hud a.s., but denying or disobeying one messenger of Allah means denying or disobeying all of His messengers. Because all the messengers carry the same task, which is to invite people to believe in the oneness of Allah and obey His commands and avoid His prohibitions.
text.60:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the people of 'Ad, who continuously rebelled in disbelief, were afflicted with Allah's curse in this world, so that they were all destroyed by a violent and extremely powerful wind. This will be followed by a more painful and more terrible torment on the Day of Judgment.

Furthermore, Allah warns all His servants to realize that this is the recompense for the disbelieving people of 'Ad, who denied the Oneness of Allah the Almighty, who created them. They also rejected His messengers arrogantly and stubbornly, only in pursuit of fleeting worldly gains.

Then, at the end of this verse, Allah clearly states that destruction is upon the people of 'Ad who have strayed far from Allah's mercy. They are the people of Hud (peace be upon him) who did not believe in Hud (peace be upon him) and the message he brought, so they received a curse in this world and in the Hereafter.
text.61:
In this verse, Allah explains that He sent a messenger to the people of Thamud, whose name was Saleh. He called upon them to worship Allah and abandon the deities that had led them to a path that was wrong and misleading. It is Allah who created them from the earth. From the earth He created Adam a.s., and from the earth is the origin of all mankind. After humans multiplied on earth, they were entrusted with the task of developing it, as a gift and favor from Allah. With this favor, the people of Thamud lived happily, and they were even able to build houses to take shelter in, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"And they used to carve out dwellings from the mountains, feeling secure." (al-Hijr/15: 82)

Such was the magnitude of Allah's favor and blessings bestowed upon them. Therefore, they were obligated to be grateful for these blessings by glorifying and exalting Him and not worshipping anything besides Him. And they should have repented to Him for their excesses in committing errors, worshipping deities other than Him. If they had realized this and sincerely repented to Him, surely Allah, the Most Gracious, the Acceptor of Repentance, would have forgiven them and included them among the righteous. This is what Prophet Saleh a.s. called for and encouraged his people to do.
text.62: The Prophet Salih's call, which was so good and accompanied by acceptable reasons and strengthened by the promise that they would receive forgiveness from Allah, the Most Gracious, was flatly rejected by his people. They answered: "O Salih, you were the focus of our hopes, because you are a respected person, a wise and prudent man, a descendant of noble people among us, and we believed that you would be able to lead us to the right path. But all our hopes have been dashed by your call. We are amazed, why do you forbid us from worshiping our gods who have been our objects of worship and those of our ancestors since ancient times?"
text.63: Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him) answered the accusations and challenges of his people by stating that his call was a true call for their own good and happiness, if they would only think about it and consider it. Prophet Saleh asked them to consider it carefully, if it turned out that he was right and could present evidence from God for the truth of his call. Was it possible for him to disobey Him and refuse to convey this call to his people? Who could help him if Allah destroyed him for that disobedience? He had to convey this truth and explain to them that the objects of worship and idols could not help them in the slightest. Therefore, worship Allah who created them and gave them blessings and favors so that they could live happily on this earth.
text.64: Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him) told his disbelieving people that if they did not believe in his call, then Allah had sent a special she-camel as proof of the truth of his call. This camel was very different in nature and behavior from ordinary camels, both in terms of its eating and drinking, as well as its temperament and characteristics. They were forbidden to disturb it and were to let the camel eat and drink in the place it liked. If they dared to disturb or abuse it, they would surely be afflicted with punishment from Allah.
text.65: But the people of Thamud still did not believe him and continued to oppose and mock him, even killing the camel that Allah had sent as a miracle. Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him) was very saddened by the actions of his people, because he was certain that they would be destroyed by Allah because of their act of killing the camel. Then Prophet Saleh said, "You are given the opportunity by Allah to enjoy life in this land for three days, and after that you will be destroyed because of your denial and disobedience. This is a promise from Allah, which will surely be fulfilled, and you will see it for yourselves."
text.66: When the calamity that Allah had threatened the people of Thamud with arrived, as punishment and retribution for their disobedience, Allah SWT saved Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him) and those who believed with him, by His grace and mercy, from that torment and punishment. On that day, those who were disobedient were all destroyed. They earned a bad name in human history, which will certainly be regarded as a black mark that tarnishes the purity and high dignity of humanity as caliphs on earth. Indeed, the punishment that Allah inflicted upon them was very severe, but that action was just and in accordance with the sins and errors they committed. Allah is the One who has the right to do so and He is the One who can carry it out because He is the All-Powerful and the All-Capable.
text.67: The people of Thamud were destroyed by Allah with a thunderous, deafening sound, shaking the hearts of every listener and causing a terrible earthquake, so that the sinful and disobedient people fell prostrate unconscious and were swallowed by the earth that had cracked and split apart. Not one of them could save themselves from that catastrophe.
text.68: Indeed, the calamity that befell them was so terrible that in an instant they were all destroyed, as if they had never existed on the face of the earth, as if their homelands had never been inhabited by humans, lost and vanished, swallowed up by disaster. All of this was a consequence of their disobedience to Allah and their denial of the miracles and proofs that He had sent down. It was fitting that they received a curse and a terrible punishment.
text.69: Some angels came to visit Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) at his house to deliver good news to him. It is narrated from Atha that the angels consisted of Jibril, Mikail, and Israfil (peace be upon them). There is also a narration that says they consisted of Jibril along with seven other angels. They were welcomed by Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) with a very good reception because he was sure that his guests, who were full of courtesy and greeted him before entering his house, were honorable guests from among good people. It was customary for the Bedouin Arabs that when guests arrived, they had to be served a special meal, according to the host's ability. Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) also served his guests a delicious meal, namely a lamb roasted on heated stones, and invited them to enjoy the special meal. But the guests did not want to touch the food, because they were angels disguised as humans, while angels do not need food and drink.
text.70: Because the guests were unwilling to touch the delicious food that was served, Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) became suspicious of their good intentions. Among the Arabs, if a guest did not eat the food that was served, it was a sign that the guest intended evil towards him. Various feelings such as suspicion, fear, and so on arose from the heart of Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and his wife, seeing the attitude of his guests. This was clearly visible on his face, which was previously radiant, then turned pale. Finally, the angels explained that they were angels sent by Allah to the people of Luth to destroy them because they were a cursed people who did not heed Allah's warning to leave their sinful and cursed deeds and believe in Allah SWT and in the message brought by Prophet Lut (peace be upon him).
text.71: The wife of Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him), named Sarah, became happy and smiled because those who came were not evil people, but rather angels, messengers of Allah, and of course they would not eat or drink. Furthermore, they said to Sarah that Allah had conveyed good news for her that she would give birth to a son named Ishaq (Isaac), and Ishaq would also have descendants, among them Yaqub (Jacob).
text.72:
Sarah was very surprised when she heard the angel's words, as if she couldn't believe that those she faced were angels who never lied and would never be untruthful. Therefore, she spontaneously replied, "How astonishing! How can I give birth to a child, when I am old and my husband is also very old!"

It is narrated that Prophet Ibrahim's age at that time was 100 years and his wife's was 90 years. According to custom, a woman who has reached the age of 50 no longer menstruates, and therefore she has no hope of having children. Moreover, Sarah was also a barren woman, as mentioned in Allah's word:

Then his wife came forward, crying aloud, and struck her face, saying, "(I am) an old woman, barren." (az-Zariyat/51: 29)

Prophet Ibrahim a.s. was no less surprised to hear the news, as mentioned in Allah's word:

He (Ibrahim) said, "Have you come to give me good news, when old age has overtaken me? Then on what (grounds) do you give (this) good news?" (al-Hijr/15: 54)

Both of them (Prophet Ibrahim a.s. and his wife Sarah) were equally doubtful about the good news, because usually it was impossible for that to happen.
text.73:
Finally, the angels said, "Do you wonder at the decree of Allah?" It is not difficult for Allah, the Almighty and Most Powerful, to grant a child to whomever He wills, even if it is impossible according to custom and habit. It is indeed very easy for Allah, as stated in His word:

"Indeed, His command is when He intends a thing, He says to it, "Be," and it is." (Yasin/36: 82)

Furthermore, the angels said, "May Allah always bestow His mercy upon you, O family of Ibrahim (peace be upon him). He is worthy of praise and glorification."

Hearing the words of the angels, Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and his wife Sarah understood that they had gone too far and were too hasty in uttering those words, especially since those bringing the good news were the angels, messengers of Allah.

It is impossible to describe how joyful and happy Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) was, especially since his other wife, Hajar, had already given birth to a son named Ismail. They expressed gratitude and praise to Allah, who had given them a gift they had long desired and almost despaired of, because they were already old.
text.74:
After Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) knew that those who came to him were angels sent by Allah, he felt relieved and all doubts in his heart disappeared. How happy was the family of Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) at that time, there was no joy and happiness greater than that because what had long been desired and yearned for, suddenly by the grace and mercy of Allah, he would obtain a son who had already been named Isaac. But Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him), as a compassionate, loving, and caring person towards mankind, in the midst of joy, he did not forget but remembered the words of the angels, that they were sent by Allah to destroy the people of Luth. It was etched in his memory how bad the fate of the people of Luth was, and how terrible the disaster that would befall them. Happiness and joy were instantly replaced by anxiety and despair. He dared to argue with the angels, hoping that the plan to destroy the people of Luth could be canceled. This is mentioned in the word of Allah:

And when Our messengers (angels) came to Ibrahim with glad tidings, they said, "Indeed, we will destroy the people of this city [Sodom] because its people have been wrongdoers." (al-Ankabut/29: 31)
text.75: Such is the courtesy and compassion of a prophet towards mankind, especially Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) who, in a state of joy and happiness, was about to obtain the desire and dream of his heart that he had long aspired to, namely a son named Isaac from his first wife. In such a state, people usually forget everything, but he did not forget the fate of the people of Luth, whom he heard were to be destroyed, and he pleaded with his Lord that they be saved, presenting reasons and hopes that his request would be granted. Indeed, Prophet Ibrahim was truly one who was forbearing and had compassion for those afflicted with misfortune and always surrendered himself to his Lord.
text.76: Finally, the angels firmly said to Ibrahim, rejecting his earnestly presented request. Do not discuss the fate of the people of Luth and surrender their affairs to the decision of your Lord. Allah has decreed concerning them that they will be afflicted with a punishment that cannot be rejected, because they are a people who deny His commands and have committed sins and transgressions that are very evil and disgusting. Their sins cannot be forgiven anymore; they have been given the opportunity to repent and return to the straight path, but all good da'wah and calls were always rejected, instead met with mockery and ridicule. That is the decision of your Lord, the Most Just. They and their land will be destroyed by sinking it into the earth.
text.77: When the angels of Allah came to Lot, in the form of handsome young men, he felt distressed by the arrival of those guests. He was already worried that his people would surely harass them because the young men attracted their attention, because they were inclined towards men, not women. Prophet Lot, peace be upon him, felt his chest tighten because of the arrival of those guests, so he said, "This is the most difficult and most dangerous day."
text.78:
The people of Lot came to him rushing, like people driven by evil desires. They had long been committing vile acts, strongly condemned by natural human instinct, and even more so by religious law. They indulged in homosexuality, engaging in sexual relations with men instead of women, and they openly committed various evils in their meeting places. Allah says:

"Do you approach men, and cut off the road, and commit evil in your meetings?" (al-Ankabut/29: 29)

Prophet Lot, peace be upon him, said, "O my people, here are my daughters, and the daughters of my people, you may marry them. They are purer for you, and you can associate with them lawfully and well, rather than satisfying your desires by committing the heinous act of homosexuality, which is extremely vile and corrupts morals and health. Fear Allah and avoid His punishment, and do not disgrace me by violating my guests, for dishonoring a guest is the same as dishonoring the host. Is there not among you a single person with a sound mind and wisdom who can prevent you from this vile act?"
text.79: They replied, "Indeed, you have known from long ago that we have absolutely no desire for your daughters or the daughters of your people. Therefore, do not try to divert our attention from those young men by offering us your daughters, because you certainly know what we really want."
text.80: Prophet Lot, peace be upon him, said when his people still wanted to commit the homosexual crime against his guests, so that he despaired of stopping them from that vile act, "If only I had the strength and ability to prevent you, or if only I could find a group of strong people who could help me from your evils, I would certainly do it."
text.81:
After the angels who were guests of Prophet Lut (peace be upon him) witnessed the anxiety in Prophet Lut (peace be upon him), they said, "O Lut, indeed we are messengers of your Lord who have been deliberately sent to destroy them and save you from their evils. They will never be able to harm you, so calm your heart." It turned out that the sight of the people of Prophet Lut (peace be upon him) was blinded by Allah so that they could not see Prophet Lut (peace be upon him) and his guests, as explained in Allah's word:

And they had sought to seduce him concerning his guest, but We blinded their eyes. "Then taste My punishment and warning." (al-Qamar/54: 37)

Finally, they returned to their respective homes in a state of blindness, not knowing the way to their homes, they shouted for help and said that we were bewitched by the guests who were in the house of Lut (peace be upon him).

The angel said to Prophet Lut (peace be upon him), "Leave this town, along with your family and your people who believe, at the end of this night, and let no one among you be left behind or look back except your wife. Indeed, the punishment that will befall them will also befall your wife because she is an unbelieving woman who has even betrayed her husband." As for the reason why they should not look back, it is because as a result of witnessing the punishment, they will panic so that their feet will not be able to move anymore and will eventually be struck by the punishment that follows behind them. The time of the arrival of the punishment upon them is at dawn, as explained in Allah's word:

So the shriek overtook them at sunrise. (al-Hijr/15: 73)

Then the angel affirmed the certainty of the descent of the punishment with a question, "Is not the dawn near? Then quickly prepare yourselves to seek safety."
text.82: When Allah's decree came to punish the people of Lot, Allah turned their land upside down, the top falling to the bottom and the bottom rising to the top, and Allah rained down upon them stones of baked clay, falling upon them in rapid succession. Regarding the collapse of the land, according to scholars, it was due to vapors or gases emanating from its depths, and then due to the emptiness beneath the earth's layers, the land above collapsed and crumbled downwards.
text.83:
Allah sent down stones of Sijjil before the earth was overturned. According to Allah's word in Surah Adz-Dzariyat, these stones were baked clay that became stones marked by Allah Ta'ala with the names of the people upon whom they would fall. These stones were dropped in places frequently traversed by the polytheistic Quraysh when they traded to the land of Syria, so that it would be a warning to them not to oppose Muhammad, lest they be struck by a punishment like that which befell the people of Prophet Lut (peace be upon him) who disbelieved in their prophet. That place was often passed by them when they traded in the summer in the land of Syria, as explained in Allah's word:

And indeed, you (the people of Makkah) pass by them in the morning, (Ash-Shaffat/37: 137)
text.84:
In this verse, it is explained that Allah SWT sent Shu'aib as His messenger to the people of Madyan. Shu'aib was chosen from his own people. Shu'aib was a descendant of Madyan bin Ibrahim a.s. Madyan built a region for his people located in Hajar near the land of Syam, and it was named after him, so the region, its inhabitants, and its tribe were called Madyan. Shu'aib a.s., as a messenger of Allah, began his missionary work by inviting his people to worship Allah and forbidding them from associating partners with Him in the form of idols, statues, and so on, because there is no God worthy of worship except Allah, the One and Only, who created the entire universe. Then Shu'aib a.s. forbade his people from reducing measures and weights, as they did in all kinds of trade and commerce, because this act is tantamount to taking people's rights through very evil and vile deception. A similar prohibition is also explained in Allah's word:

"Woe to those who give less [than what is due], Who, when they take a measure from people, take in full, And when they give a measure or weight to them, cause loss." (al-Muthaffifin/83: 1-3)

Shu'aib a.s. explained to his people that he saw them living in abundance and wealth, they did not need to commit fraud in measures and weights. Because, besides taking the rights of others in a cunning and vile way, this also means denying the blessings of Allah who has given them much wealth. They should be grateful to Him, not the other way around, adding to their wealth with frauds and cunning that are greatly despised by Allah. Prophet Shu'aib a.s. warned his people that if they still persisted in disbelief and continued to do that reprehensible work, then he feared that they would be struck by a torment that would destroy them.
text.85:
Shuaib (peace be upon him) explained to his people what they should do regarding measuring and weighing, after first forbidding them from reducing measures and weights. The obligation was for his people to perfect measures and weights with justice, without being less or more than necessary. For the seller, what is actually forbidden is reducing measures and weights from what is due, and there is nothing wrong with adding appropriately, to ensure that the measures and weights are truly sufficient. This method is commendable, but Shuaib (peace be upon him) obligated them to act justly without being less or more. This means that in carrying out measures and weights, they must be truly meticulous.

After Prophet Shuaib (peace be upon him) forbade his people from reducing measures and weights and obligated them to perfect them, he then forbade them from all kinds of actions that reduce the rights of others, individual or collective property, whether of the type that is measured and weighed or other types such as those that are counted or that have been limited with certain boundaries. Furthermore, Prophet Shuaib (peace be upon him) forbade his people from doing anything that would damage or disturb security and peace on earth, whether related to worldly affairs or religious affairs. This verse contains laws including:

a. It is obligatory to perfect weights and measures as they should be.

b. It is forbidden to take the rights of others, in any way or means, whether that right belongs to an individual or to the public, such as government and company assets.

c. It is forbidden to do anything that is destructive or disturbs security and peace on earth, such as pickpocketing, stealing, robbing, corruption, terrorism, and others.
text.86: In this verse, Prophet Shuaib (peace be upon him) explained to his people that the lawful profit they obtained after perfecting the measure and weight was better than the unlawful profit they obtained by reducing the measure and weight, if they believed. Because faith can truly cleanse the soul from greed and avarice, and fill it with generosity. But if they did not believe, they would certainly not be able to feel it at all. Furthermore, Prophet Shuaib (peace be upon him) explained to his people that he was not the one tasked with guarding or protecting them from committing evil deeds. He was merely conveying advice and guidance to them. He had carried out that task diligently and accompanied it with warnings about Allah's punishment for those who remained disobedient.
text.87:
In this verse, Allah explains the reaction faced by Prophet Shuaib (peace be upon him) from his people as a rebuttal to the two aspects of his da'wah (call to Islam): first, that they should worship Allah, the One and Only, and not associate partners with Him by worshipping idols and the like; second, that they should perfect the measure and weight and not reduce them.

Regarding the first aspect of his da'wah, they retorted by saying, "Is it your prayer that prompts you, [O Shuaib], that we should abandon what our fathers worshipped or that we should not do with our wealth what we please?" They deliberately mentioned Shuaib's prayer because he was known for praying a lot, which became a mockery for them, as they thought his actions were madness and incoherent thoughts. When his people saw him praying, they would wink at each other and laugh at him, so prayer was among the symbols of religion that became the subject of their ridicule.

As for the second aspect of his da'wah, they retorted by saying, "Is it your prayer that commands you that we should abandon what our fathers worshipped or that we should not do with our wealth what we please? Indeed, you are the one who is forbearing and right-minded!"

According to Ibn Abbas, the praise for Shuaib (peace be upon him) was a mockery of him, and what they meant was the opposite, namely the opposite of those two qualities. This opinion is consistent with their previous conversation, which was mocking in nature and purpose.

Another opinion states that the praise remains according to its original meaning based on their initial assumption, which was before Shuaib (peace be upon him) conveyed his da'wah to them. It was as if they were saying, "You have been very forbearing and right-minded all this time, why do you want to trouble us now?" This opinion is in line with the words of the people of Thamud to Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him), which is explained in Allah's words:

"They said, "O Saleh, you were among us a man of promise before this; do you forbid us to worship what our fathers worshipped? And indeed we are, about that to which you invite us, in disquieting doubt." (Hud/11: 62)
text.88:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the response of Shu'aib a.s. to the refutation of his people by saying, "O my people, what do you think about this matter if I have clear evidence from my Lord that the da'wah (invitation/call) that I convey to you is not my own opinion but a revelation from Allah. He has bestowed upon me various good provisions. I obtain all of them in a halal (lawful) way, without reducing measures and weights and other ways that reduce or harm the rights of others in an unlawful manner. What I am telling you all is the result of experimentation and my experience in successful endeavors that contain goodness and blessings, not just based on theory or the words of inexperienced people."

Furthermore, Prophet Shu'aib a.s. explained to his people by saying, "I do not at all intend to forbid you from reducing measures and weights and other actions that reduce or harm the rights of others in an unlawful way, and then I myself do it, but from the beginning, I have been honest and have not committed deception and fraud."

Then Prophet Shu'aib a.s. said that he would not receive *taufiq* (divine guidance and success) in every step he took, except with the guidance and help of Allah. Then he stated again that he had no power and strength, only to Allah did he put his trust (*tawakkal*) in carrying out the *da'wah* that was conveyed to his people. And to Him is his return in all matters in this world, and He will recompense all his deeds on the Day of Judgment.
text.89:
In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Shu'aib (peace be upon him) clarified to his people his advice and warnings by saying, "O my people, let not your dissension with me, because you still persist in worshiping idols and statues, and oppress the rights of others by reducing measures, weights, and so on, incite and cause you to be evil people so that you are afflicted by a destructive torment in this world, like the torment of the flood that drowned the people of Noah, or the torment of the violent wind that annihilated the people of Hud, or the torment of the loud, thundering sound that killed the people of Saleh."

If the torment that befell those peoples, caused by their disobedience to Allah and His messengers, cannot be an example and lesson for you, because their time or place is far from you, then pay attention to the torment of the rain of stones that burned and destroyed the people of Lot. This event is not far in time or place from you.
text.90:
This verse explains that Prophet Shuaib (peace be upon him) commanded his people to seek forgiveness from Allah, the One and Only, by believing in Him and not associating partners with Him by worshipping idols and statues, and not reducing measures, weights, and taking the wealth of others through unlawful means. Then he commanded them to repent, that is, to return to the right path by obeying Allah and avoiding His prohibitions, because indeed Allah is Most Merciful and Compassionate towards His servants who have repented and returned to the right path by granting forgiveness and freeing them from the torment of this world and the Hereafter.

The command to seek forgiveness and repent is mentioned together, as found in other verses with almost the same meaning. However, if the command for *istighfar* is directed towards those who are still disbelievers, then the intention is not merely to seek forgiveness but to believe in Allah. As for *taubat* (repentance), it is to regret the mistakes made and return to the right path. The mistakes referred to are the mistakes committed after believing, because the mistakes committed in disbelief can be erased by believing and entering Islam.
text.91:
After the people of Madyan (the people of Prophet Shuaib, peace be upon him) became weary and annoyed with Prophet Shuaib, peace be upon him, because all the reasons they put forward to reject his call were answered by Prophet Shuaib, they finally said, "O Shuaib, we cannot understand what you are presenting to us regarding our worshipped deities and the regulations that restrict our freedom to act and control our wealth, as well as the punishment that will befall us if we do not follow your will. It is as if you are the one who determines everything, and in your hands lies our happiness and misfortune, when all of that is solely God's affair. We see and believe that you are a weak and helpless person, unable to bring benefit or harm to us, and if we wanted to destroy you, you would not be able to defend yourself. If it were not for our pity for your family and relatives, we would have stoned you to death."

They continued their rebuttal, "You yourself are hopeless and worthless to us because you are not a brave and mighty person who can defend yourself from the attacks of others. It is only out of pity for your family and relatives that we have not killed you, because they are still on our side, in our group, unwilling to abandon our religion and the religion of our ancestors."
text.92: Hearing the very hurtful words of his people, who considered him a lowly and powerless person, Prophet Shu'aib (peace be upon him) said, "How truly sad is the narrowness of your minds and how astonishing is your opinion. Do you consider my tribe more noble and more powerful than Allah who created them, created all of you, and even created the heavens and the earth? Is it only because I come from them that you do not dare carry out your threats, and not because I believe in Allah who calls you to worship Him and not associate anything with Him? For He is the All-Powerful, the All-Mighty, and the Most Generous who showers His blessings, and you take His power and mercy lightly. He is the One you should fear. He is the One you should glorify, while my tribe cannot do anything against the will of Allah. Indeed, Allah is All-Knowing of everything you do; nothing is hidden from Him. He will give a fitting recompense for your denial and disobedience."
text.93:
Then Prophet Shu'aib, peace be upon him, firmly opposed them and said to them, "Act as you please, do what you can do, and gather all the strength you have. I will remain steadfast to my creed, and I will continue to believe in Him. I am confident and certain that He will protect me and preserve me from all dangers. You will know who among us will be afflicted with torment and disaster, who among us is lying and deceitful. Wait for the fate that will befall you, and I too am waiting with you."

This is a bold challenge from someone who is helpless, has no helpers or defenders from among his people, and has no reliable strength. Yet, he is full of conviction and trust that Allah is always with him and will not neglect or waste him. This is a challenge to those who are arrogant and conceited, always boasting about material possessions but forgetting that above material strength there is a hidden power that can destroy them, namely the power and authority of Allah SWT.
text.94: It has become Allah's decree and sunnah for past communities that every community that is disobedient and rejects the call of its messenger will be afflicted with disaster and destroyed, except for those who believe and are obedient and devoted to Allah. Finally, punishment and disaster were also inflicted upon the people of Madyan, and with Allah's mercy and compassion, Prophet Shu'aib (peace be upon him) and the believers were saved from the disaster of a loud, thundering sound that shook the hearts of everyone and caused a great earthquake and tremor, so that the inhabitants of the land instantly disappeared swallowed by the earth, exactly like the disaster that befell the people of Thamud, the people of Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him) who were also disbelieving and disobedient.
text.95: The land of Madyan, after that calamity, became desolate and deserted as if it had never been inhabited by humans. Truly wretched was their fate, and they were distanced from the mercy and love of Allah because of their denial and disobedience, just like the fate of the people of Thamud.
text.96:
This verse explains that Allah sent Musa (peace be upon him) equipped with signs of His power and clear miracles, all of which demonstrate the oneness of Allah, that there is no God but Him. The scholars of tafsir agree that the signs of Allah's power that strengthened the prophethood of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) were of nine kinds: the staff, the radiant white hand, the storm, the locusts, the lice, the blood, the frogs, the shortage of fruits, and the shortage of lives. These nine signs of Allah's power have been mentioned, among others, in His words:

"Then (Musa) threw his staff, and suddenly it was a serpent, plain (to see). And he drew out his hand, and behold! it was white (with radiance) for beholders." (al-Araf/7: 107-108)

And His words:

"So We sent upon them the flood, the locusts, the lice, the frogs, and the blood as distinct signs, but they were arrogant and were a guilty people." (al-Araf/7: 133)

And His words also:

"And We certainly seized the people of Pharaoh with years of famine and a deficiency in fruits that perhaps they would be reminded." (al-Araf/7: 130)

In addition to the complete miracles given to Prophet Musa (peace be upon him), Allah also gave eloquence and the ability to argue to his brother named Harun, especially in dialogue with Pharaoh and the leaders of his people. This is what is meant by "sulthanan mubina" (a clear miracle). Some scholars of Tafsir are of the opinion that what is meant by sulthanan mubina in this verse is the staff of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him). Even though it is one of the nine signs of Allah's power as mentioned above, it is the most prominent compared to the other signs of Allah's power given to Musa (peace be upon him). With the miracle of the staff, Pharaoh's magicians turned around and collectively believed, leaving Pharaoh and his misguided beliefs, as in the words of Allah:

"And We inspired to Moses, "Throw your staff," and at once it devoured what they were falsifying. So the truth was established, and what they were doing was ruined. And they were overcome there and became debased. And the magicians fell down prostrating [in prayer]. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds, The Lord of Moses and Aaron." (al-Araf/7: 117-122)
text.97: In this verse, Allah swt explains that Prophet Musa a.s., equipped with signs of Allah's power and clear miracles, was sent to Pharaoh and the leaders of his people, so that they would worship only Allah swt, the Lord Creator of the universe, because there is no true God but Him. Even though they had seen and witnessed for themselves the signs of Allah's power and the clear miracles shown by Prophet Musa a.s., all of which demonstrated Allah swt's power, they did not want to be aware. Instead, they continued to obey Pharaoh's commands, even though Pharaoh was not right, and did not bring any good, but only caused destruction and led astray.
text.98:
This verse explains that Pharaoh had caused corruption on earth and misled his people in the world. In this verse, Allah SWT explains that in the Hereafter, he will lead his people to the place that has been prepared for them. He walks in front, and his people follow him from behind until they reach hell, then they are thrown into it together. How wretched and at a loss are Pharaoh and his people, because hell is the worst place to arrive at. Even since they left this world, every day, morning and evening, hell is always shown to them, as Allah SWT says:

"Then Allah protected him from the evils of their plots, while the people of Pharaoh were enveloped by the worst torment. The Fire: they are exposed to it morning and evening. And on the Day the Hour will be established (it will be said), "Admit the people of Pharaoh into the severest punishment." (al-Mumin/40: 45-46)
text.99:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that Pharaoh and his people, since in this world, have received curses from the people after them, continuously, until in the hereafter they will be cursed again by the people who are in Padang Mahsyar, waiting for the decision from Qadhi Rabbul Jalil about where they will be placed later. The curse they receive is one of the worst things. This verse is in line with Allah SWT's saying:

And We caused a curse to pursue them in this world, and on the Day of Resurrection they will be among the despised. (al-Qashash/28: 42)
text.100:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the events that occurred to previous communities and important incidents in cities and villages, from the people of Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) to the people of the prophets after him, are deliberately included in the Quran so that Prophet Muhammad can recite them to mankind and so that they can be read by people after him to be used as lessons and warnings.

Among the countries that have been destroyed, some still have visible traces like plants that still stand upright on the earth, such as the land of the people of Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him). There are also those that have no traces at all, like plants that have been harvested and leave no trace whatsoever, such as the land of the people of Prophet Lot (peace be upon him) which was turned upside down.
text.101:
This verse explains that their destruction was not an act of injustice from Allah, but rather they themselves wronged themselves, which caused Allah to take such action. They associated partners with Allah and continuously caused damage on earth, so that the punishment could not be delayed. If they were left in such a state for a prolonged period, they would certainly remain, and even increase their oppression, wickedness, and destruction on earth, as Prophet Noah (peace be upon him) said about his people to Allah:

"If You leave them [alive], they will mislead Your servants and will beget none but wicked and ungrateful [children]." (Nuh/71: 27)

The messengers who were sent to them were persistent enough in giving lessons and guidance, but they remained arrogant and disobedient. When threatened, they became even more defiant and opposed because they were too confident that their worshipped deities would save them from all dangers and punishments that would befall them. Whereas, if Allah SWT has decided to send down punishment and destroy a people, then the objects of worship they invoke besides Allah SWT will not benefit them in the slightest and have no power whatsoever to restrain and prevent Allah's decree. Their belief in their objects of worship only adds to their destruction and ruin. They believed that these objects of worship would inflict calamity upon the prophet who was sent, as Allah SWT narrated in His word regarding the people of Prophet Hud (peace be upon him):

"We only say that some of our gods have afflicted you with evil." (Hud/11: 54)
text.102:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that the torment inflicted upon the lands of the people of Noah, the people of 'Ad, and the people of Thamud will also be inflicted upon all lands whose inhabitants continue to be characterized by and constantly commit corruption on the face of the earth. No people will escape or be spared from it if Allah swt wills it. The Prophet Muhammad saw said:

"Indeed, Allah swt postpones the punishment for the oppressors until when He punishes them, He will not let them escape." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari, Muslim, and at-Tirmidzi from Abu Musa al-Asyari)

Indeed, the punishment of Allah is very severe. The above explanation can serve as a lesson, especially for the oppressors, so that they become aware and repent of their evil deeds. There is no effort or power, no matter how great, that can prevent or stem the punishment of Allah that He will inflict upon a land or a people. Allah swt says:

"Have they not traveled through the earth and seen what was the end of those before them? They were superior to them in strength, and they tilled the earth and populated it more than they have populated it, and their messengers came to them with clear proofs. And Allah would never have wronged them, but they were wronging themselves." (ar-Rum/30: 9)
text.103:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that what has been narrated about the destruction of past communities as a result of the oppression they committed, serves as a lesson for those who are willing to be aware and fear the torment of the Hereafter. Allah, who punished them in this world, is certainly able to punish them in the Hereafter, and what surrounds them in this world is a picture and example of what they will encounter in the Hereafter.

Events such as typhoons, earthquakes, landslides, and so on, which destroy property and countless lives, are punishments and warnings from Allah swt to humans to realize their mistakes, sins, and oppressions, and not just natural disasters that have nothing to do with the power of Allah swt. Before such things happen, the messengers of Allah have warned their people of something that will happen, so that they are careful. All of this shows that these events are not coincidental, but are closely related to Qadha and Qadar, one of the pillars of faith that must be believed and trusted. Pay attention to the word of Allah swt:

And those who have wronged will know to what [kind of] return they will be returned. (ash-Shu'ara/26: 227)

Those who do not want to be aware of Allah's warnings in this world will be punished later in the Hereafter, on the day when all creatures will gather to be reckoned for all their deeds, and then rewarded with the fairest of justice. This event is witnessed by all creatures, whether humans, jinn, angels, or other creatures.
text.104: In this verse, Allah explains that the Day of Resurrection is the day when all creatures will gather and witness all their deeds, and each person will be asked to account for their deeds in the world. It will not be delayed or prolonged, but will end according to what Allah SWT has determined.
text.105:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that when the appointed day arrives, no one can speak or do anything except with Allah's permission, as stated in His words:

"This is the Day when they will not speak, And they will not be permitted to make an excuse." (al-Mursalat/77: 35-36)

And His words:

"On the Day the Spirit and the angels will stand in rows, they will not speak except for one whom the Most Merciful permits, and he will say what is correct." (an-Naba/78: 38)

Among the people gathered on the Day of Judgment, some will be wretched, they will receive a painful punishment as has been threatened to the disbelievers, and some will be happy, they will obtain rewards and eternal pleasure in accordance with what has been promised to the pious.
text.106: In this verse, Allah swt explains that those who belong to the group of the wretched are those who, while they were in the world, corrupted their faith, followed those whose actions were misguided, so that the light of faith faded and was extinguished from them, wallowing in sin throughout their lives. They will be cast into Hell and experience a painful torment, like a donkey exhaling and inhaling its breath accompanied by groans and very loud cries.
text.107: They will abide in Hell forever, except if Allah SWT wills otherwise, for He is the Executor of what He wills. Whatever He wills will come to pass, and whatever He does not will will not exist.
text.108:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that those who are fortunate because when they were in the world they were always careful and avoided actions that contradict Allah's commands and stayed away from temptations that would plunge them into the valley of sin, they will be placed in Paradise, and abide therein forever, unless Allah swt wills otherwise. The reward and blessings bestowed upon the fortunate are purely a gift from Allah swt that is continuous and never-ending, in accordance with His word:

"They will have a reward uninterrupted." (at-Tin/95: 6)
text.109: In this verse, Allah swt comforts the Prophet Muhammad saw and gives a warning to his enemies. And for the polytheistic idol worshippers, Allah will surely punish them for what they worship, just as their ancestors worshipped. Just as their ancestors were punished for their actions of opposing the prophets and worshipping idols, so too will befall them, without any reduction whatsoever.
text.110:
In this verse, Allah swt explains that He gave the Torah to Musa a.s., then the Torah was disputed by his people, whether the Torah was truly from Allah or not. Some of them believed that the Torah was truly from Allah and others denied it. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad need not be upset if he sees the disbelievers of Mecca doubting the Qur'an, both its content and its truth. If there were no decree from Allah to postpone (punishment) for the unjust and disbelieving until the appointed time, Allah would surely have punished them as He had punished and destroyed those who opposed the da'wah of the messengers before the Prophet Muhammad saw. In line with the content of this verse, Allah says:

"And never think that Allah is unaware of what the wrongdoers do. He only delays them for a Day when eyes will stare [in horror]." (Ibrahim/14: 42)

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that those who deny the Book of Allah are truly in deep doubt and uncertainty, as Allah says:

"And they (the People of the Scripture) did not become divided until after knowledge had come to them - out of jealous animosity between themselves.
