And if not for a word that preceded from your Lord [postponing the punishment] until a specified time, judgment would have been settled between them. And indeed, those who were granted inheritance of the Scripture after them are, concerning it, in disquieting doubt." (asy-Syura/42: 14)
text.111:
In this verse, Allah SWT affirms that those who dispute the truth of the Al-Quran and doubt its coming from Allah, then Allah will perfect the recompense for their deeds, both in this world and in the hereafter, because Allah is All-Knowing of what they have done. Allah says:

"That is for what your hands have put forth [of evil]. And indeed, Allah is not unjust to [His] servants." (ali Imran/3: 182)

And His saying:

"Whoever does righteousness - it is for his [own] soul; and whoever does evil [does it] against it. And your Lord is not ever unjust to [His] servants." (Fushshilat/41: 46)
text.112:
This verse provides guidance to the Prophet Muhammad saw regarding what he should do when his people launch challenges and doubt the Quran he brought. He is commanded to remain steadfast in his stance, walk on the straight path, convey the sharia entrusted to him, carry out his mission, and never let it cross his mind to abandon any part of what has been revealed to him, because of the cruelty of his people's slander, as Allah says:

"Then perhaps you (Muhammad) would give up a part of what is revealed to you, and your breast would feel constrained by it..." (Hud/11: 12)

Likewise, those who have become aware and repentant from polytheism and disbelief and have believed with Muhammad saw should remain steadfast in their stance, maintain their monotheistic creed, and never deviate from the straight and true path that they have believed in and are convinced of, because Allah sees and knows all of that. In line with this verse, Allah says:

"So to that [religion of Islam] invite, [O Muhammad], and remain on a right course as you are commanded and do not follow their inclinations but say, "I have believed in what Allah has revealed of the Book, and I am commanded to do justice among you. Allah is our Lord and your Lord. For us are our deeds, and for you are your deeds. There is no [need for] argument between us and you. Allah will bring us together, and to Him is the [final] destination." (ash-Shura/42: 15)
text.113:
In this verse, Allah SWT emphasizes that those who believe in the Prophet Muhammad and adhere to his religion should never incline towards the oppressors, namely the enemies of the Muslims who constantly harm them, and the polytheists who constantly try to return them to polytheism. They should never seek help and assistance from them, as if they have made them their leaders, because if it reaches such a degree, then those believers will be included as being like them, who will not receive guidance. Allah says:

"Whoever among you takes them as allies, then indeed, he is [one] of them. Indeed, Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people." (al-Maidah/5: 51)

The only one who can be made a leader and asked for help and assistance is Allah. Whoever does otherwise, then he is among the oppressors who have no helper, as Allah says:

"And there will be for the wrongdoers no helpers." (al-Maidah/5: 72)
text.114:
This verse commands the Muslims to establish prayer, complete with its pillars and conditions, to be performed five times a day and night according to the appointed times, namely Fajr (Subuh), Dhuhr, and Asr, Maghrib, and Isha prayers. In line with this verse is the word of Allah:

"So glorify Allah in the evening and in the morning (time of Fajr). And to Him is [due all] praise in the heavens and the earth. And [exalt Him] in the [late] afternoon and when you are at noon (Dhuhr)." (ar-Rum/30: 17-18)

This verse also explains that good deeds, which broadly consist of carrying out Allah's commands and avoiding His prohibitions, including performing prayer, will erase minor sins and bad deeds. This is in line with the saying of the Prophet Muhammad (saw):

"Follow up a bad deed with a good deed, and it will erase it." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Abu Dharr al-Ghifari)

And the word of Allah:

"If you avoid the major sins which you are forbidden, We will remove from you your lesser sins and admit you to a noble entrance [into Paradise]." (an-Nisa/4: 31)

Previous messages such as the command to be steadfast (istiqamah), the prohibition of injustice and siding with the wrongdoers, and the command to establish prayer are lessons and reminders for those who are conscious and aware, who always remember Allah.
text.115:
In this verse, Allah swt commands us to be patient. What is meant by patience in this verse is steadfastness and endurance in facing all difficulties in carrying out Allah's commands and avoiding His prohibitions. Patience and prayer are twin deeds that can be used as helpers to overcome all difficulties faced, so that one can easily reach what is aspired to. There are many verses that encourage patience and prayer to be used as helpers. Among them is Allah's saying:

"O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient." (al-Baqarah/2: 153)

And His saying:

"So be patient, [O Muhammad], over what they say and exalt [Allah] with praise of your Lord before the rising of the sun and before its setting; and during periods of the night exalt [Him] and at the ends of the day, that you may be satisfied." (Taha/20: 130)

This verse ends with an affirmation that Allah will not waste the reward of those who do good, such as being patient, but Allah will perfect their reward, as He says:

"Only those who are patient will be given their reward without measure." (az-Zumar/39: 10)
text.116:
In this verse, Allah swt expresses His condemnation of intelligent and clever people who do not prevent their fellow human beings from causing corruption on earth, even though the sound minds and intelligent thoughts they possess are sufficient to understand the goodness proclaimed by the messengers. Only a few of them use their sound minds, thoughts, and intelligence to forbid evil and enjoin good. It is these few who are saved by Allah. The intelligent and wise people of the past who were unjust prioritized excessive luxury and pleasure, which caused them to become arrogant, conceited, and wicked (fasiq). They opposed the messengers' call to goodness, and even did the opposite. Evil spread, and none of them forbade others from doing evil. Because the sins they committed were too heavy, Allah destroyed them. Allah says:

"And when We intend to destroy a city, We command the affluent among them [with obedience], but they commit disobedience therein; so the word comes into effect upon it, and We destroy it with [complete] destruction." (al-Isra/17: 16)
text.117:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that He will not destroy a country if its inhabitants still do good, do not commit injustice such as reducing weights and measures as the people of Prophet Shuaib AS did, do not commit *liwath* (homosexuality, sodomy) as the people of Prophet Lut AS did, do not obey their cruel and tyrannical leaders, as Pharaoh did, and other evils, because such things are injustice. Allah will not command such things. Allah says:

"And never will your Lord be unjust to [His] servants." (Fushshilat/41: 46)

And His saying:

"Indeed, Allah does not wrong the people at all..." (Yunus/10: 44)
text.118:
This verse explains that if Allah willed, then humanity would be one community in religion, in accordance with the original fitrah of their creation. Even though initially humanity was one community without any disputes among them, after they multiplied, different needs and desires arose, and thus endless differences and disputes emerged, as Allah says:

And mankind was not but one community; then they differed. (Yunus/10: 19)
text.119: Their disagreements are not only about the religions adhered to by each group, such as Judaism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, Islam, or shirk, but also among adherents of the same religion, except for those who receive mercy from Allah and are granted taufik and hidayah. These people are united and always strive for unity so that people obey Allah's rules and regulations, do what He commands, and avoid what He forbids. Such is Allah's will regarding the diversity of mankind. Some receive mercy, taufik, and hidayah from Allah; they are united and build unity, and they belong to the group of happy people who will be inhabitants of Paradise. There are also those who constantly disagree, and they belong to the group of unfortunate people who will be inhabitants of Hell. Malik bin Anas once said, "Mankind was created, some to be in Paradise and others to be in the Hellfire (sair)." Therefore, Allah concludes this verse with a firm statement that it has become His decree to fill Hell (Jahanam) with jinn and humans who always commit evil and sin on this earth.
text.120: This verse explains that the stories of the previous messengers with their people, such as the debates and hostilities between them, the complaints of the prophets because their people denied and harmed them, and so on, are all useful for strengthening the heart of the Messenger of Allah so that he is not shaken by anything in carrying out his prophetic duties and spreading his da'wah. In addition, these stories also instill a firm and deep conviction about what the messengers called for, such as the creed that Allah is One, repenting and worshipping Him sincerely, abandoning evil, both apparent and hidden. All of this is a lesson and a reminder that is beneficial for the believers that the previous people were afflicted with torment because they had committed injustice and corruption on earth.
text.121: In this verse, Allah swt commands Prophet Muhammad saw to say to the disbelievers, "Act according to your position and ability to oppose the da'wah and harm those who preach it along with their supporters. And We will act according to Our position and ability to defend the da'wah and carry out Allah's commands, and be obedient and submissive to Him." This is a threat to them about the punishment they will receive as a recompense for their actions.
text.122:
In this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to say to the disbelievers who remain defiant to the Messenger that they should wait for what will happen with the Messenger's da'wah (call to Islam), and what calamity will befall the Messenger, which they greatly hope for, as explained in His word:

"Or do they say, "[He is] a poet for whom we await a misfortune of time?" (ath-Thur/52:30)

Then the Messenger is commanded to say to them that he is also waiting for what will happen to their fate, whether they will be punished by Allah, or whether they will be defeated by the believers, in the battles that will occur between the two sides, just like the fate received by previous peoples who defied their prophets. Indeed, Allah guarantees victory for those who defend the religion, and defeat and humiliation for the wrongdoers. These verses are similar to Allah's word:

"You will come to know who will have the [best] outcome of the Home. Indeed, the wrongdoers will not succeed." (al-An'am/6:135)
text.123:
This verse explains that Allah knows the unseen and what is beyond the reach of anyone's knowledge, whether in the heavens or on earth. He knows everything that will happen and the precise time it will occur. All matters will return to Him. What He wills will surely come to pass, and what He does not will will not exist. Therefore, He is the only One who deserves and is obligated to be worshipped, with all sincerity. To Him we must put our trust (tawakal) in order to achieve something beyond our capabilities, because whoever puts their trust in Him, their needs will be fulfilled. Allah says:

"And whoever relies upon Allah - then He is sufficient for him. Indeed, Allah will accomplish His purpose. Allah has already set for everything a [decreed] extent." (ath-Thalaq/65: 3)

At the end of this verse, Allah SWT explains that He will not be negligent of what His servants have done. He will perfect the recompense for every deed done in this world, and there will be no reduction whatsoever.

Allah says:

"And fear a Day when you will be returned to Allah. Then every soul will be compensated for what it earned, and they will not be treated unjustly." (al-Baqarah/2: 281)
